unnormalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about common units used in medicine, especially here in India. It's a good question 'cause things can get confusing!
normalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about common units used in medicine, especially here in India. It's a good question because things can get confusing!

unnormalised: So, first off, for measuring medicines, you'll often see things like "mg" (milligrams) or "ml" (milliliters). Think your Paracetamol 500mg or a cough syrup dose of 5ml. Doctors also talk about "mcg" or "µg" (micrograms), which are even smaller. For injections, they might use "IU" (International Units), especially for things like insulin. And don't forget about "cc," which is the same as ml, you'll hear older doctors saying "2cc" instead of 2 ml.
normalised: So, first off, for measuring medicines, you'll often see things like "milligrams" or "milliliters." Think your Paracetamol five hundred milligrams or a cough syrup dose of five milliliters. Doctors also talk about "micrograms" or "micrograms," which are even smaller. For injections, they might use "I-U" (International Units), especially for things like insulin. And don't forget about "c-c," which is the same as milliliters, you'll hear older doctors saying "two c-c" instead of two milliliters.

unnormalised: When they're talking about your body, you might hear things like "cm" (centimeters) for height. "kg" (kilograms) is the usual for weight, of course. Blood pressure is measured in "mmHg" (millimeters of mercury) – you'll see something like 120/80 mmHg, that's normal. And for body temperature, it's either degrees Celsius (°C) or Fahrenheit (°F). Just remember 37°C is roughly 98.6°F.
normalised: When they're talking about your body, you might hear things like "centimeters" for height. "kilograms" is the usual for weight, of course. Blood pressure is measured in "millimeters of mercury" – you'll see something like one hundred and twenty slash eighty millimeters of mercury, that's normal. And for body temperature, it's either degrees Celsius or degrees Fahrenheit. Just remember thirty seven degrees Celsius is roughly ninety eight point six degrees Fahrenheit.

unnormalised: Hope that helps clear things up a bit! Always best to ask your doc or pharmacist if you’re unsure about anything. They're the real pros!
